Award.AwardTitle: Shape and Size of Pulsar Emission Regions via Statistics of Scattering
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will study the sizes and shapes of pulsar emission regions, using interstellar scattering as a lens. It will derive the sizes and elongations of the emission region of the Vela pulsar as a function of pulse phase, providing images or a short movie over sizes of a few hundred kilometers, and improving understanding of pulsar emission. The project will advance the mathematical description of signals from a scattered source, and should lead to improvements in correlators. The work includes 1) installing a software correlator to study and correct for effects of de-dispersion, digitization, and pulsar gating; 2) improving and extending mathematical models for the intensity and interferometric visibility of small scintillating sources, including the effects of noise; 3) measuring the variation of source size, elongation, and position angle as a function of pulse phase, for the Vela pulsar; and 4) measuring, or at least setting limits on, the sizes of emission regions of older, slower pulsars.

This work will form the bulk of a graduate student's thesis, and will include undergraduate physics majors via theses and summer projects. Through a weekend science program, the project will also introduce local high-school students to conversion of sound to electricity and back, and to signal processing by computer to supplement the ear and brain in deciphering sound.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We used scattering of radio waves in interstellar space to how pulsars emit radio waves. Pulsars are neutron stars: the extremely dense cores that remain after supernova explosions of high-mass stars. If they rotate rapidly and have strong magnetic fields, they  launch streams of electrons and positrons from their surfaces. These streams in turn emit radiation across the electromagnetic spectrum, from radio waves to gamma rays. The precise location and mechanism of radiation remains uncertain. It is likely within or not far outside the speed-of-light cylinder, where co-rotating matter must travel at the speed of light. 
 
Interstellar space contains hot gas, in the form of ions and free electrons. The free electrons interact with radio waves to deflect and scatter them, so that radiation from a nearly pointlike source arrives at Earth from a variety of directions. If this scattering were organized into large structures acting as lenses, they would form an image of the pulsar at the Earth: the same optical principles govern scattering and imaging. In principle, from scattering one can determine both the spatial structure of the source and the distribution of scattering material. The goal of our project was to extract as much information as possible on the structures of pulsars and on the scattering material, from observations using a network of radio telescopes around Earth and in space.  

We began our work with a study of the effects of noise on radio-astronomical signals. Usually, "noise" is the random part of a measurement, whereas "signal" is the nonrandom part. As well as background noise, and "source noise" from the random emission of the pulsar, the quantities we wished to measure, scattering effects and source intensity (and probably source structure to some degree), are all random. We created a theoretical model that described background noise, source noise, and the effect of intermittent emission from the source, as well as the effects of propagation and scattering. We found excellent agreement with our measurements, and published the results in scientific papers. 

A second major effort was our study of the scattering of pulsars, and of other astrophysical radio sources, by the interstellar plasma. Using networks of radio telescopes on Earth, often in concert with the Russian RadioAstron telescope in high Earth orbit, we discovered two major categories of effects.  One we dubbed "cosmic prisms": large-scale gradients in the density of ionized gas are responsible for much of the effects of scattering.  These gradients act in precisely the same way as prisms, to deflect and disperse radiation. In addition to their effect in scattering effects, such prisms are likely to affect timing of pulsars, for studies of gravitational radiation.  The other category we call "substructure". We found that the scattered images are not smooth, but contain much internal structure.  This structure varies, both over short times of a few seconds and over much longer times of days to weeks. We performed theoretical calculations of how such substructure might arise. We searched for substructure in other types of radio sources. We found substructure in images of the Galactic Center radio source, SgrA*, thought to be the closest supermassive black hole. We used substructure to set observational constraints on the properties of the plasma that strongly scatters this important source. The effects of substructure will significantly affect imaging of SgrA* by the Event Horizon Telescope at submillimeter wavelengths. We also showed that scattering can introduce fine structure where none exists, for example in images of active black holes at the centers of other galaxies. We pointed out that substructure  explains the small-scale structure that RadioAstron and Earth-based networks of radio telescopes observe in these sources at longer wavelengths. Results were again reported in a number of papers. 

The third major effort was to determine the size of a pulsar's emission region. This involved corrections for the effects discussed above, as well as modeling the effects of source structure on the statistics of scattering. From observations at 18 cm wavelength, we found that the size of the emission region had size of up to 1000 km at the beginning and end of the pulse, although nearly zero at the center. Indeed, geometry of the pulsar emission suggests that the pulsar should appear largest at the beginning and end of the pulse.  This contrasted with observations of the same pulsar at 49 cm wavelength, where the size was less than about 100 km when averaged over the entire pulsar.  The emission is thought to be more coherent at the longer wavelength; a spatially coherent source will appear as a point source. The pulse at the longer wavelength also resembles the central part of that at the shorter wavelength. These considerations may explain the apparent difference in the results. Again, we published papers on these results.
